snippet: A rewrite could collapse in partisan disarray. But it could also herald a new era of education, keeping some testing but eliminating prescriptive punishments.
abstract: No Child Left Behind law, which has been criticized by both parents and teachers as over-reliant on testing, is facing possibility of rewrite that would eliminate punishments for schools that fail to meet testing standards; some warn that new version of law could allow states to lower academic standards or reduce funds for needy schools.

byline.original: By MOTOKO RICH and TAMAR LEWIN
byline.contributor: Motoko Rich reported from Cleveland, and Tamar Lewin from Philadelphia.

lead_paragraph: A rewrite could collapse in partisan disarray. But it could also herald a new era of education, keeping some testing but eliminating prescriptive punishments.

headline.main: No Child Left Behind Law Faces Its Own Reckoning
headline.print_headline: No Child Left Behind Faces Its Own Reckoning
